newsitem.title: UK: US-French CFMI sees sales growth, ups output.
newsitem.headline: US-French CFMI sees sales growth, ups output.

text.p: Franco-U.S. aero engine maker CFM International expects to virtually double sales in two years and will boost production to keep up with a dramatic upturn in the commercial airline market, senior executives said on Wednesday.

CFMI expects to post 1996 turnover of $2.7 billion, up from $2 billion in 1995 and forecasts $4.6 billion in 1998, president and chief executive officer Gerard Laviec told reporters at the Farnborough air show.
It expects to deliver 450 engines this year, up from 389 in 1995 and took orders for 772 compared with 550 last year.
This year is the second year the order book has oustripped deliveries, adding to the order backlog, he said.
The company is a 50/50 joint venture between French Engines, a unit of General Electric.
Laviec said he had upgraded his sales forecast for 1996 to around 1,000 engines from around 800.
Output will rise to meet demand and the firm expects to deliver around 800 units in 1998.

Although sales are growing, so is competition. "Competition is killing the market in big 'planes," he said. Faced with discounts which far exceed 10 percent, CFMI was determined not to sell at a loss, he said. "We will not give our engines away."
CFMI is developing a derivative of its CFM56 family, the CFM56-9, which will be offered to the 100-seater AE100 passenger 'plane planned by China, Singapore and the European AIA joint venture.
Aero International Asia is a joint venture between French state-owned Aerospatiale, British Aerospace Plc and Alenia, a unit of Italy's Finmeccanica SpA.
The CFM56-9 will have thrust of 18,500 to 23,000 pounds thrust.
CFMI accounts for between 15-20 percent of sales of GE Aircraft Engines, and 60-70 percent of Snecma turnover.
